details.title: Fuzzy Multi-State Systems: General Definitions, and Performance Assessment

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Mech. Eng., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, AB

p: Yi Ding received his B.Eng from Shanghai Jiaotong University, China; and Ph.D. from Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, respectively. Currently he is a Postdoctoral Research Fellow in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Alberta, Canada. His research interests focus on reliability & availability evaluation and optimal design, power systems operation and power market.

authors.name: Yi Ding

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Mech. Eng., Alberta Univ., Edmonton, AB

p: Ming J. Zuo received the Bachelor of Science degree in agricultural engineering in 1982 from Shandong Institute of Technology, China; and the Master of Science degree in 1986, and the Ph.D. degree in 1989 both in industrial engineering from Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa, U.S.A. He is currently Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Alberta, Canada. His research interests include system reliability analysis, maintenance planning and optimization, signal processing, and fault diagnosis. He is Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Area Editor of the International Journal of Performability Engineering, and Editorial Board Member of International Journal of Quality, Reliability and Safety Engineering. He also served as Department Editor of IIE Transactions (2005–2008). He is a senior member of IEEE and IIE. He received the 2006, and the 2008 IIE Golomski Awards, and the Best Paper Award at the 2005 IIE Industrial Engineering Research Conference.

authors.name: Ming J. Zuo

p: Anatoly Lisnianski is an Expert-Engineer in the Reliability Department at The Israel Electric Corporation Ltd., and holds a visiting position at Haifa University, Israel. He received his M.Sc. degree in electrical engineering and computer science from the Institute of Precision Mechanics and Optics in Sankt-Petersburg, Russia; and Ph.D degree in reliability from Federal Scientific & Production Center “Aurora”. His research interests are in reliability, risk analysis, applied probability, and statistics. He is author, and coauthor of several books, and more than 80 scientific papers in these fields. He is a senior member of IEEE.

Zhigang Tian is currently an Assistant Professor at the Concordia Institute for Information Systems Engineering (CIISE) at Concordia University, Canada. He received his B.S. degree in 2000, and M.S. degree in 2003, both in mechanical engineering at Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China; and his Ph.D. degree in 2007 in mechanical engineering at the University of Alberta, Canada. His research interests focus on reliability analysis and optimization, condition based maintenance, and prediction. He is a member of IIE, and INFORMS.

details.abstract: Compared with a binary system model, a multi-state system model provides a more flexible tool for representing engineering systems in real life. In conventional multi-state theory, it is assumed that the exact probability and performance level of each component state are given. However, it may be difficult to obtain sufficient data to estimate the precise values of these probabilities and performance levels in many highly reliable modern engineering systems. New techniques are needed to solve these fundamental problems. A general fuzzy multi-state system model is proposed in this article to overcome these deficiencies. The basic definitions and assumptions of such systems are introduced. The concepts of relevancy, coherency, and equivalence are used to characterize the properties of such systems. Future research directions include performance evaluation algorithms for the defined fuzzy multi-state systems.

references.title: Multi-State System Reliability Assessment, Optimization, Applications

context.text: However, for some engineering systems, the binary assumption does not accurately represent the possible states that each of the systems may experience [1].
Examples of insightful summaries of reported MSS studies are given in [1], [8], [9].

In [19], the fuzzy universal generating function (FUGF) was developed to extend the universal generating function with crisp sets, which is widely used in the reliability evaluation of conventional MSS [1].

references.text: A. Lisnianski, G. Levitin, Multi-State System Reliability Assessment Optimization Applications, 2003, World Scientific.

links.abstract: This paper generalizes a redundancy optimization problem to multi-state systems, where the system and its components have a range of performance levels-from perfect functioning to complete failure. The components are: (1) chosen from a list of products available in the market; and (2) characterized by their nominal performance level, availability and cost. System availability is represented by a multi-state availability function, which extends the binary-state availability. To satisfy the requir...

references.text: G. Levitin, A. Lisnianski, H. Ben-Haim, D. Elmakis, "Redundancy optimization for series-parallel multi-state systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 47, no. 2, pp. 165-172, 1998.

references.title: Optimal Reliability Modeling Principles and Applications

context.text: Examples of insightful summaries of reported MSS studies are given in [1], [8], [9].

Comparing definition 2 with the definition of strong relevancy in a conventional MSS [8], the condition for component \$i\$ to be strongly relevant to a MSS is identical to that for it to be fuzzy strongly relevant to a FMSS.
Comparing with the definition of relevancy in a conventional MSS [8], the relevant condition in the fuzzy domain is relaxed.
Moreover, comparing with the definition of weak relevancy in a conventional MSS [8], the state change of the system can be only possible.

However, comparing Definition 5 with the definition of a conventional MSS [8] for the homogenous system, relaxed is the condition that when all components are in the same state the system is also definitely in the same state.

references.text: W. Kuo, M. J. Zuo, Optimal Reliability Modeling Principles and Applications, 2003, John Wiley & Sons.

links.abstract: This paper constructs a new k-out-of-n model, viz, a weighted-k-out-of-n system, which has n components, each with its own positive integer weight (total system weight=w), such that the system is good (failed) if the total weight of good (failed) components is at least k. The reliability of the weighted-k-out-of-n:G system is the complement of the unreliability of a weighted-(w-k+1)-out-of-n:F system. Without loss of generality, the authors discuss the weighted-k-out-of-n:G system only. The k-ou...

references.text: J. S. Wu, R. J. Chen, "An algorithm for computing the reliability of a weighted- \$k\$ -out-of- \$n\$ system", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 43, no. 2, pp. 327-328, 1994.
